head.title: U.S. Judge Refuses to Extradite Lawyer Back to Colombia on Drug Charges

hedline.hl1: U.S. Judge Refuses to Extradite Lawyer Back to Colombia on Drug Charges

block.p: A federal judge refused today to extradite a 36-year-old Colombian lawyer facing drug trafficking charges in his homeland, saying that the Colombian government could not close a ''great big hole'' in its evidence linking the man to the crime.

The suspect, Victor Manuel Tafur-Dominguez, a graduate student at Pace University Law School in White Plains, who worked for an anti-drug program in Colombia, would have been the first Colombian national extradited from the United States on drug charges under a 1979 treaty his father helped write.

A federal judge refused today to extradite a 36-year-old Colombian lawyer facing drug trafficking charges in his homeland, saying that the Colombian government could not close a ''great big hole'' in its evidence linking the man to the crime.

The suspect, Victor Manuel Tafur-Dominguez, a graduate student at Pace University Law School in White Plains, who worked for an anti-drug program in Colombia, would have been the first Colombian national extradited from the United States on drug charges under a 1979 treaty his father helped write.

Mr. Tafur-Dominguez's father, Donald Rodrigo Tafur, a former Colombian senator, was killed in March 1992 outside his home in Cali during a wave of violence linked to the extradition of Colombian drug suspects to the United States, a procedure the treaty also sanctioned.

The charges in Colombia, where Mr. Tafur-Dominguez is accused of helping to finance a $120 million shipment of cocaine that was seized in December 1998, are still pending, and Mr. Tafur-Dominguez said he would fight them from here.

Colombia has the right to resubmit its extradition request at any time with amplified evidence; officials there have been quoted in Colombian newspapers in recent weeks as saying that if Mr. Tafur-Dominguez was not extradited it could affect future extradition of Colombian nationals to the United States.
A spokeswoman at the Colombian Embassy in Washington said the government would not have an immediate comment.

''It's very risky there right now,'' Mr. Tafur-Dominguez said of Colombia, after a two-hour hearing today in which his lawyer, Joseph A. Tate, and Justice Department lawyers representing Colombia argued over what both sides agreed was conflicting evidence linking Mr. Tafur-Dominguez to the charges.
''I think it was a fair hearing that the judge has given us and I'm going to keep working on this until it is all over,'' Mr. Tafur-Dominguez said.

Mr. Tafur-Dominguez, who was arrested March 4 near Philadelphia while traveling with his family to a flower show, drew passionate support from classmates and professors at Pace University who doubted that the quiet student they knew could be involved in such a crime.

Mr. Tafur-Dominguez had fought the drug trade as assistant director of a Colombian government program that encourages farmers to grow crops other than coca. He nearly died in a plane crash in the Andes in March 1999, on his way to a village to explain the program.
He went to the United States to recuperate near his mother, who lives an hour's drive north of Philadelphia. He enrolled at Pace last August to study environmental law.
Supporters said they believed that Mr. Tafur-Dominguez had been framed by drug traffickers, and a Justice Department lawyer said last month that 12 people connected to the case had been killed.
To win its case for extradition, Colombia must prove that probable cause exists that Mr. Tafur-Dominguez knowingly committed a crime.

But Magistrate Judge Charles B. Smith ruled today that Colombia had nothing in its extradition papers proving that Mr. Tafur-Dominguez was aware that his checks were used in the cocaine deal. ''I honestly don't think I can find probable cause here,'' he said. ''We've got this great big hole in the evidence.''

The case centered on 13 checks Mr. Tafur-Dominguez had written to a currency trader to exchange 512 million pesos for $350,000, the sum of his mother's government pension from her husband's death. Mr. Tate and Mr. Tafur-Dominguez said it was a legitimate transaction to get a more favorable exchange rate than that offered by commercial banks.

Mr. Tafur-Dominguez put the $350,000 in a Swiss bank account for safekeeping and had a bank statement for the deposit. But the checks later turned up in the accounts of a dummy company that Colombian officials said was behind the seven-ton cocaine shipment, among the largest seized in that country.
